channel.title: NYT > U.S. News

item.title: Private Autopsy Shows Renee Good Was Shot at Least 3 Times, Lawyers Say
item.description: Lawyers for the family of Ms. Good, who was fatally shot by an immigration agent in Minneapolis, have said their firm was conducting an investigation into the shooting.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman
item.media:description: A memorial for Renee Good was left on a snowy Minneapolis corner.

item.title: ICE Said Agents Can Enter Homes Without Judicial Warrant, Group Claims
item.description: A whistle-blower group said a memo apparently signed by the leader of Immigration and Customs Enforcement violated constitutional protections against unreasonable search and seizure.
item.dc:creator: Hamed Aleaziz
item.media:description: Federal immigration agents performed an operation to arrest two people at a home in Minneapolis this month.

item.title: Cuban Detainee in El Paso ICE Facility Died by Homicide, Autopsy Shows
item.description: The report from the county medical examiner said the detainee, Geraldo Lunas Campos, was asphyxiated and restrained by law enforcement. Federal officials described his death as a suicide.
item.dc:creator: Pooja Salhotra
item.media:credit: Paul Ratje for The New York Times
item.media:description: Camp East Montana, a U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement detention facility at Fort Bliss in El Paso.

item.title: Former Uvalde Officer Adrian Gonzales Found Not Guilty of Endangering Children in Mass Shooting
item.description: Adrian Gonzales had faced 29 charges for his actions in the 2022 shooting, in which 19 children were killed by a gunman at Robb Elementary School in Texas.
item.dc:creator: Edgar Sandoval
item.media:credit: Christopher Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Memorials honoring the victims of the Robb Elementary school shooting in Uvalde, Texas.

item.title: Illinois Investigates Claim That Landlord Tipped Off High-Profile ICE Raid
item.description: The state said it has opened an investigation into whether the management of a troubled South Side building may have called federal agents to try to help clear out Black and Hispanic tenants.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:description: An apartment building in Chicago’s South Shore neighborhood where federal agents staged a raid last fall.

item.title: Trump’s ‘Board of Peace’ Would Have Global Scope but One Man in Charge
item.description: The initiative is the latest example of the president dismantling the post-World War II international system and building a new one, with himself at the center.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Allison Robbert for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israel, Saudi Arabia and other nations have said they would join President Trump’s proposed “Board of Peace,” but France, Norway and Sweden have said no.

item.title: At Davos, a Clash Between Trump’s World and the Old World
item.description: For decades, leaders have gathered in Davos to discuss a shared economic and political future. On Wednesday, President Trump turned the forum into a bracing clash between his worldview and theirs.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: Audience members listening to President Trump’s address at Davos on Wednesday.

item.title: T.S.A. Leader Defends Working With ICE to Congress
item.description: At an oversight hearing, Democratic lawmakers peppered the agency’s acting director over the Transportation Security Administration’s role in Trump’s immigration crackdown.
item.dc:creator: Adam Sella
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Ha Nguyen McNeill, the acting T.S.A. director, speaking to lawmakers at an oversight hearing at the Capitol on Wednesday.

item.title: Dozens Are Sickened by a Rare Fungal Infection in Tennessee
item.description: One person who contracted it died. The fungus is commonly found in soil in the Ohio River and Mississippi River valleys, and the illness is not contagious.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:description: This image created from a microscope in 1964 shows histoplasmosis of the lung.

item.title: Supreme Court Hearing Reveals Unease Over Threats to Fed Independence
item.description: As the justices weighed the consequences of allowing President Trump to fire a Federal Reserve official, the president reprised his pressure campaign on the central bank.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith and Tony Romm
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lisa D. Cook, a Federal Reserve governor whom President Trump tried to fire last year over allegations of mortgage fraud.

item.title: Inside the Push to Protect Candidates From Political Violence Ahead of 2026 Elections
item.description: Two leaders of a political security group talked about what they’re seeing and hearing.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: Liam James Doyle for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial for Melissa Hortman, the former speaker of the Minnesota House, who was assassinated last June.

item.title: RFK Jr., Kicking Off National Tour, Says He’s Not Running for President
item.description: Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. rallied supporters at the Pennsylvania State Capitol, where he promoted his new dietary guidelines.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. held a rally on Wednesday at the Pennsylvania State Capitol to mark the start of a national “Take Back Your Health” tour.

item.title: Austin Thompson Pleads Guilty in North Carolina Shooting That Left 5 Dead
item.description: It is highly uncommon for mass shooters to plead guilty in a country where such attacks seem all too frequent. The man’s lawyers said he wanted to spare the community from further trauma.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:credit: Veasey Conway for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial at the Hedingham Golf Club in Raleigh, N.C., in 2022, honoring the slain victims. The shooter pleaded guilty on Wednesday to all the charges against him.

item.title: Federal Agent Fires Gun During Immigration Operation in L.A. Area, Officials Say
item.description: The authorities said an agent fired his weapon at a man in Compton, Calif., who was being pursued over a human smuggling operation. The man was not struck.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan, Orlando Mayorquín and Johnny Diaz

item.title: Military Police Troops Put on Alert for Possible Deployment to Minnesota
item.description: The move was described as precautionary in the event that President Trump invokes the Insurrection Act in response to protests.
item.dc:creator: Greg Jaffe
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Federal immigration agents in Minneapolis last week.

item.title: Barbara Aronstein Black, a First as a Law School Dean, Dies at 92
item.description: A legal historian, she broke a gender barrier as the first woman to lead an Ivy League law school, serving as dean of Columbia Law from 1986 to 1991.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Schachar

item.title: House Panel Votes to Hold Clintons in Contempt in Epstein Inquiry
item.description: The votes by the Oversight panel were bipartisan, though many Democrats said the charges were extreme given Bill and Hillary Clinton’s willingness to answer questions.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
item.media:description: Representatives James R. Comer, right, Republican of Kentucky and the chairman of the House Oversight Committee, and Robert Garcia of California, its ranking Democrat, during Wednesday’s session.

item.title: Court Removes Restrictions on ICE’s Use of Pepper Spray, for Now
item.description: The Eighth Circuit granted the Trump administration’s request to block, for the moment, a lower court’s injunction limiting how federal agents interact with protesters in Minnesota.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith
item.media:description: Federal officers clashed with protesters after Renee Good was shot and killed in Minneapolis earlier this month.

item.title: 4 Takeaways from Supreme Court Hearing on Trump’s Firing of Lisa Cook
item.description: The justices were alert to the central bank’s crucial role and wary of issuing a broad ruling based on rushed briefing and incomplete information.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak and Colby Smith
item.media:description: Lisa Cook, a federal reserve governor, with her attorney Abbe Lowell, outside the Supreme Court on Wednesday.

item.title: Greenland Advises Residents to Have 5 Days of Supplies
item.description: The semiautonomous Danish territory issued its guidance as President Trump told European leaders that he wouldn’t send troops to seize it. Greenland said it was responding to power cuts, not geopolitics.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Maya Tekeli
item.media:credit: Sigga Ella for The New York Times
item.media:description: Downtown Nuuk, Greenland, last year. Residents of the island were advised by the government on Wednesday to prepare to be self-sufficient for five days.

item.title: Rahm Emanuel Calls for Age Limit of 75 for President, Congress and Judges
item.description: The former Chicago mayor, who is trying to shape the Democratic Party’s future and might run for president, said that “across all three branches of government, 75 years — you’re out.”
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rahm Emanuel is one of the prominent Democrats who have been most active in trying to guide the party’s direction.

item.title: Trump Administration Backs Down in D.E.I. Schools Lawsuit
item.description: The administration withdrew its challenge to a ruling halting its effort to strip funding from schools and colleges with D.E.I. programs. It did not say why.
item.dc:creator: Dana Goldstein
item.media:description: Randi Weingarten, president of the American Federation of Teachers, spoke at a rally in March. The federation, another professional association and a school district in Oregon brought the lawsuit.

item.title: Did the U.S. Ever Own Greenland? Fact-Checking Trump’s Davos Speech.
item.description: The president gave misleading accounts of the U.S. role in Greenland’s history and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, among other claims.
item.dc:creator: Linda Qiu
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Trump speaking at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, on Wednesday.

item.title: Stephen Hess, 92, an Eminent, and Quotable, Political Scientist, Dies
item.description: A Brookings Institution scholar, he advised presidents and wrote books on the media (assessing reporters in one) and government (including a study of beleaguered press officers).
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden

item.title: Newsom Says Trump Team Barred Him From U.S. Pavilion at Davos
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California accused the Trump administration of cutting off his access to the American pavilion, where he was scheduled to speak on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler
item.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California said he was denied entry to the American pavilion in Davos, Switzerland, where he was scheduled to speak later on Wednesday.

item.title: Trump Suggests Switzerland Tariffs Stemmed From Friction With Swiss President
item.description: Speaking at the World Economic Forum on Wednesday, Mr. Trump said he raised tariffs on Switzerland last year to among the highest in the world after a phone call with the country’s president.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Karin Keller-Sutter, speaking as Switzerland’s president at the United Nations General Assembly last September. On Wednesday, President Trump described his phone call with her last year in negative terms.

item.title: Here’s a Look at Everything (and Everyone) Trump Targeted at Davos
item.description: President Trump’s verbal broadsides drew gasps and nervous laughter at the annual gathering of political and business leaders.
item.dc:creator: Erin Mendell and Shashank Bengali
item.media:description: President Trump addressing the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, on Wednesday.

item.title: Trump Administration Starts Immigration Operation in Maine
item.description: A similar operation that unfolded in Minnesota became a flashpoint between protesters and immigration authorities.
item.dc:creator: Hamed Aleaziz
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal immigration agents in Minneapolis last week.

item.title: After promising to reveal new U.S. housing policies in his Davos speech, Trump offers few details.
item.description: President Trump and his aides have mentioned various ideas for improving housing affordability, but the specifics are still unclear.
item.dc:creator: Ronda Kaysen
item.media:credit: Travis Dove for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump issued an executive order to look into ways the government could restrict large investors from buying single-family homes.

item.title: Trump Calls Out Mark Carney in Davos Speech and Says Canada ‘Should Be Grateful’
item.description: “I watched your prime minister yesterday,” the president said in a speech on Wednesday. “He wasn’t so grateful — they should be grateful to us, Canada. Canada lives because of the United States.”
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: At the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, on Tuesday, Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada described an end to the U.S.-led world order and called on middle powers to band together.

item.title: Tariffs Case Pending as Supreme Court Takes Up 2nd Case With Economic Consequences
item.description: The timing of the court’s decision has been the subject of much speculation and anticipation. But now it may not land for at least several more weeks.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow
item.media:description: President Trump has imposed sweeping tariffs on imports from nearly every U.S. trading partner.

item.title: Trump Confuses Iceland and Greenland in Davos Remarks
item.description: “Our stock market took the first dip yesterday because of Iceland,” the president said, referring to market shifts related to his repeated threats to seize Greenland. “So Iceland’s already cost us a lot of money.”
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Juliette Pavy for The New York Times
item.media:description: A protest against President Trump for his threats to take over Greenland in the territory’s capital, Nuuk, on Saturday. Mr. Trump has repeatedly confused Greenland with Iceland, its North Atlantic neighbor.

item.title: Michelle Obama and Gretchen Whitmer Disagree on America’s Readiness for a Female President
item.description: As Mrs. Obama defended her remarks from November that the country wasn’t ready for a woman as president, Gov. Gretchen Whitmer of Michigan offered a different view.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer
item.media:description: Michelle Obama in November. In a new interview, she said she could eventually foresee a woman as president, but asked: “Are we ready now? I don’t know. Prove us wrong. I would love that.”

item.title: Canadian Former Flight Attendant Posed as Pilot to Get Free Flights, Prosecutors Say
item.description: Federal prosecutors accused Dallas Pokornik of using false identification to get hundreds of free flights from three unnamed airlines, which he denied.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: A flight attendant at Toronto Pearson International Airport last year.

item.title: Trump Tried to Fire Lisa Cook on Social Media. Is That Due Process?
item.description: In addition to disputing whether the president had sufficient cause to remove her, the Fed governor said the way he went about it was a separate problem.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:description: The Supreme Court will consider whether the law requires Lisa D. Cook, a Federal Reserve governor, be afforded due process in her firing.

item.title: Trump Drops Tariff Threats Over Greenland After Meeting With NATO Chief
item.description: President Trump’s announcement appeared to draw the United States back from the possibility of military and economic conflict with American allies over Greenland.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes, Jim Tankersley and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: Hours after his address to the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, on Wednesday, President Trump said he had reached a framework agreement with the leader of NATO over the future of Greenland.

item.title: Fed’s Independence in Flux as Supreme Court Weighs Lisa Cook’s Ouster
item.description: How the justices rule in the case between President Trump and the Federal Reserve governor will affect the central bank’s ability to set policy without political interference.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: On Wednesday, Supreme Court justices will hear arguments on the case revolving around Lisa D. Cook, a governor at the central bank who is suing President Trump for trying to fire her.

item.title: The fate of the Fed may turn on two words: ‘for cause.’
item.description: The Supreme Court has said the Federal Reserve Board’s independence warrants protection. President Trump’s effort to fire a member will test that commitment.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:description: No president before President Trump has tried to fire a Federal Reserve governor.

item.title: Who are the lawyers arguing over Trump’s effort to fire Lisa Cook?
item.dc:creator: Abbie VanSickle
item.media:description: President Trump’s solicitor general, D. John Sauer, will defend the president’s firing of Lisa Cook.

item.title: For Trump, the Supreme Court Case Reflects Goal to Remake the Fed
item.description: The president has spoken repeatedly of his desire to install a majority of political loyalists on the board of the rate-setting central bank.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm
item.media:description: Stephen Miran, one of the president’s economic advisers, joined the Federal Reserve Board of Governors last year.

item.title: E.U. Delays Mercosur Trade Deal With South America
item.description: The move by the European Parliament delays a push by the bloc to find new trading partners, as President Trump has threatened escalating U.S. tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:description: Members of the European Parliament voting to refer the Mercosur trade deal to Europe’s top court.

item.title: What Is Lisa Cook, the Fed Governor, Accused of Doing?
item.description: The Trump administration has accused Lisa D. Cook, a Fed governor, of engaging in mortgage fraud, but financial documents cast doubt on the claims.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lisa Cook has served on the Federal Reserve Board of Governors since 2022.

item.title: Trump’s retribution efforts have struggled with mortgage cases.
item.description: The sputtering push to bring charges against Letitia James, the New York attorney general, underscores the challenges the administration has faced in accusing her of mortgage fraud.
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett
item.media:description: Bill Pulte, the director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency, has targeted several rivals of President Trump with investigations into their mortgages.

item.title: A Brief From Every Living Former Fed Chair Could Sway the Justices
item.description: The filing, also signed by six former Treasury secretaries, said that letting President Trump fire Lisa Cook would deal a blow to the credibility of the nation’s monetary policy.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:description: Former chairs of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve including Alan Greenspan, left, and Janet Yellen, signed the amicus brief.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow

item.title: Michele Tafoya Announces Senate Run in Minnesota
item.description: Ms. Tafoya, once a sideline reporter for N.F.L. games, has more recently turned her focus to Republican politics. She is seeking an open seat now held by a Democrat.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti
item.media:description: Michele Tafoya joins a fledgling Republican primary field in the race to replace Senator Tina Smith, a Democrat who is retiring.

item.title: Greenland Shouldn’t Overshadow Ukraine, NATO Chief Says
item.description: Helping Ukraine defend against Russian aggression should be Europe’s “No. 1 priority,” Mark Rutte, the secretary general of NATO, said in Davos.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Mark Rutte, the secretary general of NATO, cautioned about complacency on Ukraine.

item.title: Supreme Court to Weigh Trump’s Bid to Fire Lisa Cook
item.description: The Supreme Court is hearing oral arguments on Wednesday in the case of Lisa Cook, the Federal Reserve governor whom President Trump is trying to fire. Our reporter Colby Smith describes the importance of Cook’s case for the independence of the central bank.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith, Sutton Raphael, Gabriel Blanco, James Surdam, June Kim and Nikolay Nikolov

item.title: NATO brass meet for ‘frank’ talks amid the Greenland feud.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:description: Adm. Giuseppe Cavo Dragone, the Italian chair of NATO’s military committee, speaking last year.
